info.name: Express CIAM Beta APIs
info.description:
The ForgeRock Identity Cloud includes two sets of APIs:

* Management APIs: To manage configuration of Express CIAM 

* Authentication APIs: To authenticate users and obtain and manage `access_token`, `id_token` and `refresh_token`

item.name: Management APIs
Apps
Native/Spa Apps

body.raw:
{
  "accessTokenLifetime": 3600,

    "refreshToken": true

  "jwtSigningAlgorithm": "RS256",

  "loginRedirectUris": ["https://example.com/homeLogin/"],
  "logoutRedirectUris": ["https://example.com/homeLogout/"],
  "name": "Sample Native/Spa App",
  "refreshTokenLifetime": 604800,
  "type": "spa"
}

request.description:
Creates a Native/SPA app. Returns the app configururation.

The reponse contains a client ID to be used when authenticating a user to this application.  Because Native and SPA apps are unable to protect a secret, a secret is not used when authentication with this type of app.

Include: `"type" : "spa"` in the payload to specify the type of app to be created in Express CIAM

response.name: Create a Native/SPA App

item.description:
Create, update, and delete Native/SPA apps. The OAuth 2.0 spec calls these apps public apps because they are unable to protect a client secret. 

Each time you create a *new* Native/SPA app in Express CIAM, our test script will store the public client ID in a postman variable `natspaClientId` and `clientId`, which is used by the other API calles in the Native/Spa Apps collection.

request.description:
Creates a web app client in Express CIAM. 

Include: `"type" : "web"` in the payload to specify the type of app to be created in Express CIAM

*Note*: In this example call the `password` client grant type to true.  Use `password` client grant for non-production environments and use authorization code or client crendial grants for production.

item.description:
You can create, update, and delete, and regenerate a client secret Web apps. The OAuth 2.0 spec calls these apps as confidential apps because they are able to store their client secret.  

Each time you create a *new* Web app in Express CIAM, our test script will store the public client ID and secret in the postman variables `webClientId`,`webSecret`, and `cliendId` which are used by other API calles in the Web Apps collection.

request.description:
Creates a Service app in Express CIAM 

Include: `"type" : "m2m"` in the payload to specify the type of app to be created in Express CIAM and set `"clientCredentials" : "true"`


Each time you create a *new* Web app in Express CIAM, our test script will store the public client ID and secret in the postman variables `m2mClientId` and `m2mSecret`, which are used by other API calles in the Serivce (M2M) Apps collection.

item.description:
Create, update, and delete, and refresh the client secrest for Service apps called M2M apps in Express CIAM.  Machine to Machine apps are categorized as confidential clients due to their ability to store the client secret.

Each time you create a *new* M2M app in Express CIAM, our test script will store the m2m client ID and secret in the postman variables `m2mClientId` and `m2mSecret`, which are used by other API calls in the M2M Apps collection.

request.description: Returns a paged list of end users. You can limit output based on filters and parameters, as discussed in our documentation on Querying Users.

response.name: Get users

request.description: Returns a paged list of end users. You can limit output based on parameters with conditions, as discussed in our documentation on Querying Users. This call provides a model, with the following options added to the endpoint: * *parameter*: May be `filter`, `startIndex`, `count`, `fields`, `sortBy` * *userProperty*: Set to any valid user property * *comparator*: Use an operator that compares JSON values * *value*: Must be a valid value The example request shown in the right-hand column performs a conditional search for users, with the following options: * `filter` (*parameter*) that searches for a * `userName` (*userProperty*) that's set * `eq` (equals) (*comparator*) to * `bjensen@example.com` (*value*). The `%20` and `%22` in the example request URI represent a space and a double-quote, respectively, encoded in UTF-8 format. Based on the example request, you'll see user information for `bjensen@example.com` in the example response.

response.name: Get users with search filter

request.description: Sends the user an email containing a link to a password reset page.  The password reset page is the `destinationUrl` parameter specified in the request payload.

item.description:
Manage the global password policy for users of the tenant. Use the GET Password Policy call to review the current password policy, in JSON format. You can then use the output to format your desired password policy, through the Set Password Policy call.

- The password age is set in `days`.
- The password lock duration is set in `minutes`.
- You can disable numeric options such as `maxPasswordAge` by setting them to 0.

For a more complete discussion, see our documentation on [Password Policies](https://developer-cloud.forgerock.com/api-reference/password-policies/).

item.description: The /hosted-pages endpoint allows you to list and add/modify pages to host on your app.

The Management API allows you to manage objects (including users).With your apps, you can exchange a client ID and secret for an access token and call the API using the token.  

Some of these apps require the access_token for your ui-{{tenantName}}.forgeblocks.com app. You can get this token from the developer console for your browser, as the `Authorization: Bearer` token under Request Headers.

item.description: The API calls for the UsernamePassword Authentication flow follow the same path our JavaScript SDK for UsernamePassword do to authenticate a user.  A successful outcome returns a users `session token`. Our postman collection stores this in a postman environment variable called `sessionToken` which are used to get an `access_token` and `IdToken` for the authenticated user.

request.description: Gets the SSO Token for the user, also known as the `iPlanetDirectoryPro` token.

response.name: Second Factor Response Step 4

item.description:
The API calls for the SecondFactor Authentication flow follow the same path our JavaScript SDK for SecondFactor do to authenticate a user and uses Email as the chosen method to receive the SecondFacor. 

To successfully authenticate with this API collection, you will need access the email address associated with the authenticating user's profile.  And you will need to collect the code send in the email and populate the `OneTimePassword` prior to the POST call on Step 4.

A successful outcome returns a users `session token`. Our postman collection stores this in a postman environment variable called `sessionToken` which are used to get an `access_token` and `IdToken` for the authenticated user.

You can use the Authtication APIs to authenticate a user for Express CIAM.  These APIs will return what we call a session token.  When a session token is returned via these APIs, our scripts store them in a variable called `sessionToken` which is used to obtain an `access_token`.

item.name: Get Access Token - Native or SPA Apps

request.description:
Uses the session token and SPA Client ID to produces an authorization code. This authorizatoin code is used in the next API call to exchange it for the user's `access token`

*Note*: A 302 message is expected; this REST call includes a script which reads authorization code from the result and sets a postman variable authorizationCode to be used in the next API call in this collection.

item.name: Exchange Authorization Code to Access Token

request.description:
Takes the authorization code from step 2, along with the Native/SPA app client ID, to get the access token using Proof Key for Code Exchange (PKCE). 

To enhance security, the REST call uses a unique authorization code instead of the app client secret.

item.description:
You are able to obtain an `access token` for these types of apps using these APIs.  Unlike Web Apps, Native/Spa apps are unable to store a client secret. For confidential clients such as Native/SPA apps we can obtain an `access token` by making the following requests using the PKCE standard.

For this example we've defined an arbitrary value for the `code_verifier`, with a corresponding value for `code_challenge` in your application you will need to generate values for both `code_verifier` and `code_challenge`

item.name: Get Access Token - Web Apps

request.description:
Uses the SSO token and web app credentials to produce an authorization code.

*Note*: A 302 message is expected; this REST call includes a script which pulls the authorization code from the verbose output for step 3.

item.name: Exchange Authorization Code to Access Token

request.description:
Takes the authorization code from step 2, along with the Web app client ID, to get the access token using Proof Key for Code Exchange (PKCE). 

To enhance security, the REST call uses a unique authorization code.

Even though the REST call includes the base64 encoding of the client ID and client secret, PKCE enhances security for web apps, as it prevents a malicious user from using:

* An intercepted authorization code
* Data from a request to the /authorize endpoint (as shown in step 2)

item.description:
This section helps secure access tokens without client secrets. 

For Native/SPA apps, this is critical; otherwise, client secrets would be stored on end-user devices and browsers. 

For Web apps, it reduces risks, as malicious users can't use an intercepted authentication code.

Security is ensured by a `code_verifier` and `code_challenge`. A `code_verifier` is a cryptographically random string. The `code_challenge` depends on the value of `code_challenge_method`. 

* If `code_challenge_method` = `plain`, `code_challenge` = `code_verifier`.
* If `code_challenge_method` = `S256`, `code_challenge` = `BASE64URL-ENCODE(SHA256(ASCII(code_verifier)))`.

For the purpose of this REST collection, we've set up an arbitrary value for the `code_verifier`, with a corresponding value for `code_challenge`.

Get Web App Token - Password Grant

urlencoded.description: As allowed by your web app
As defined for your app. *Note*: include a space (not a comma) between each scope.

request.description:
Requires credentials for an existing user, based on a web app. This call sets up a base64-encoded value for the web app via `Basic Auth` under authentication, using the Client ID and Client Secret for the web app.

*Note*: This REST call requires manual configuration of the *Password* grant type for the subject web app. If you've set up a different user and password, adjust the REST call accordingly.

Returns tokens specific to a user:
* access_token
* refresh_token
* id_token

Prerequisite: You can run this REST call after running the following calls:

* Create a New Web App
* Create User

The output from these calls automatically populates the variables needed here. You can also substitute the variables of your choice.

If you modify scopes, make sure they correspond to active scopes for your app.

request.description:

This works with the `check_session_iframe` URL seen in the GET Discover REST call.

response.body:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<!--
  ~ DO NOT REMOVE COPYRIGHT NOTICES OR THIS HEADER.
  ~
  ~ Copyright 2013-2019 ForgeRock AS. All Rights Reserved
  ~
  ~ Use of this code requires a commercial software license with ForgeRock AS.
  ~ or with one of its affiliates. All use shall be exclusively subject
  ~ to such license between the licensee and ForgeRock AS.
  -->
<html lang="en">
    <head>
        <meta charset="utf-8">
        <meta name="description" content="OpenIDConnect checkSession">
        <title>OpenIDConnect checkSession</title>
    </head>
    <body style="display:none">
        <script src="https://openam-sampletenant.forgeblocks.com/am/js/sha256.js"></script>
        <script type="text/javascript">
            window.addEventListener("message", receiveMessage, false);
            var client_id;
            function receiveMessage(e){
                data = e.data.split(' ');
                client_id = data[0];
                var clientURI = "";
                if (e.origin !== clientURI){
                    return;
                }
                var session_state = data[1];
                var opbs = getBrowserState();
                var ss = CryptoJS.SHA256(client_id + e.origin  + opbs).toString();
                if (session_state == ss) {
                    stat = 'unchanged';
                } else {
                    stat = 'changed';
                }
                e.source.postMessage(stat, e.origin);
            }

            function getBrowserState(){
              var validSession = false;

              if (!validSession){
                   return "";
               }
               var cookieName = "iPlanetDirectoryPro" + "=";
               var cookies = document.cookie+";";
               var cookieStart = cookies.indexOf(cookieName);
               if (cookieStart != -1) {
                   var end = cookies.indexOf(";", cookieStart);
                 return unescape(cookies.substring(cookieStart + cookieName.length, end));
             }
             return "";
         }
        </script>
    </body>
</html>

request.description:
End the current session. Requires the id_token created for the user, which is set to id_token_hint. You get an id token when you get an access token for a web app, a native spa app, or the password grant and you specify openid as part of the scopes.

This endpoint returns a 302 upon success and redirects to the specified post logout uri.
Returns ID Token information

item.description: APIs to manage your ID Tokens

Supports authentication of users to access apps. Some Authentication API endpoints support creation of app and user access tokens. You can then use those access tokens in the Management API. You can use these REST calls to build authentication into your apps. To take full advantage of the Management API, include appropriate scopes in requests to authorization endpoints. The Authentication API then includes the scope in the output access token. For more information, see our documentation on scopes.
